events.target_title: Add a Fit Content Zoom mode
Add a Fit Content Zoom mode

note.body:
Nope it's not the same. I've attached a quick mockup of what I meant. The red parts are just text and the blue bar is the header of the document.

As you can see, in one image you have the fit width mode (that has white margins on each side of the document) and on the other the fit content mode (that doesn't show any lateral white margin).

It looks similar to fit width but the difference is that it hides the unused lateral margins. The extra zoom you get doing this is really useful for smaller screens or when you try to open 2 documents side by side on the screen.

This is not a bug, it's more like a feature proposal. Hope it's a bit more clear now :)

events.target_title: Add separator for XPath results.
Add separator for XPath results.

note.body:
I think you would like to give users a choice of the separator rather than designate as `\n`. This is because some nodes may contain `\n` as part of their text. In this case, users can use another separator that their text doesn't contain to allow for further processing.

I can give an example here:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
    <menu>
        <food>
            <name>Hot
    Chocolate</name>
            <price>$1.99</price>
        </food>
        <food>
            <name>Iced
    Tea</name>
            <price>$2.99</price>
        </food>
    </menu>

You can compare these two commands and their results:

    # xmllint --xpath "//food/name/text()" --xpath-node-separator "\t" a.xml | xargs -d "\t" -n 1 echo item
    item Hot
    Chocolate
    item Iced
    Tea
    # xmllint --xpath "//food/name/text()" --xpath-node-separator "\n" a.xml | xargs -d "\n" -n 1 echo item
    item Hot
    item Chocolate
    item Iced
    item Tea

events.target_title: Add separator for XPath results.

note.body:
I agree that support for `\0` would be great. Actually what I was trying to do initially was to support `\n` and `\0`. However, I found the underlying xml output functions (ex: `xmlBufAdd`) might not have good support for output of `\0`. This is largely because `\0` is the same as `NULL` and a `NULL` argument means nothing (but not a `\0` char) in the semantics of those functions. So I decided, for backwards compatibility, to not touch that part for the moment, but leave the possibility of doing so, with a custom xpath separator. Once it's clear how to patch those xml output functions, it'd be easy to fully support `\0` as a valid separator.

----

It's not some hypothetical user. People start asking for this feature ever since 2013:

-   <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14726951/xmllint-problems-to-output-lines/52460174>
-   <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18532948/how-to-append-a-newline-after-every-match-using-xmlint-xpath/51596538>
-   <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30225075/get-url-from-xml-node-with-xmllint-add-new-line/52460177>

----

`doc/xmllint.xml` has been updated in the newer commits. These commits also removed the new function `xmlSaveTreeWithSep`, but instead augmented `xmlSaveTree` directly with an additional parameter. I think this functionality belongs to this inner function. Doing it outside would make the calling code too complicated and would require you to write it again if you need to use this function at other places.

push_data.commit_title: Regenerate man page and html doc.
Separate nodes in nodeset result by newline or null.

events.target_title: Add separator for XPath results.

note.body:
If you can confirm `xmlOutputBufferWrite(buf, 1, "\0")` works as intended (maybe some docs should be added  because passing in string length different from the result of `strlen` on a string looks non-standard) then I'm happy with supporting only `\n` and `\0`, because it works with xargs and allows users to translate `\0` into other separators they want. However, I think supporting `\n` alone is not enough and can be quite confusing, especially when it's a breaking change, much for the same reason I showed in earlier threads, plus, when users find their old script no longer works but the program doesn't offer other options.

In your last commit https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/commit/da35eeae5b92b88d8ebdb64b4b327ac1c2cf1bce there were a few `\n` directly embedded into string constants. This may cause code duplication when you try to implement `\0`, or you have to introduce another indirection to handle the difference anyway. Also, existing file `xmllint.c` doesn't call any `xmlOutput*` functions defined in `xmlIO.c` but does call several `xmlSave*` function defined in `xmlsave.c`. In this case I think reusing existing function `xmlSaveTree` looks better since it follows previous coding convention, introduces minimal code change and doesn't break compatibility.

Other than these issues, I think we agree that using `--xpath` and `--xpath0` is the way to go. So I removed custom node separators in my latest commit and use those two options instead. Users can use `tr '\0' '\n'` if they really want another separator.

events.target_title: Crashes when reading EWS Global Address List

note.body: I don't see anything that looks like a glib2 debug package in my distro. The 'devel' package is installed.

events.target_title: Crashes when reading EWS Global Address List

note.body:
Yep, you're right, I have a local GNUstep installation in *~/GNUstep* which turned out to bring its own *libffi.so.6* and put it into `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`. Very bad. Got rid of this now. But the crash still occurs. 

I get this crash each time I enter the address lists in Evolution. Hence, no, I'm getting this with `gdb /usr/libexec/evolution-addressbook-factory` at will. 

I have been getting this crash with all versions since 2.28.5 (last one I recall). Because I was getting these crashes I compiled my own RPMs using the .src.rpms for Fedora 30. Same effect.

Here is another stacktrace without that offending libffi.so.6 library:

events.target_title: File chooser opened by Qt apps does not show files with uppercase extension

note.body: Here [filechooser-portal-call.txt](/uploads/64afcb78c9b264480a4824d3526528dc/filechooser-portal-call.txt) is output from VLC file dialog. I can reproduce this using GTK dialog, but it works for me when using Qt file dialog so in my opinion this might be really issue in GTk.

events.target_title: File chooser opened by Qt apps does not show files with uppercase extension

note.body:
We have a similar problem, but from the other direction. Gtk apps can use regexp in format like ***.[jJ][pP][gG]**, which is fine for Gtk dialog, but unfortunately if Qt or KDE dialog receives this filter, they don't work with it as with regexp, but both take it as filename suffix, resulting into saving files like **foo.[jJ][pP]**, unless user change it manually in the input box, see [2] for example.

[1] - https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=402256

[2] - https://jgrulich.fedorapeople.org/qt-dialog.png

events.target_title: appDisplay: Respect X-KDE-RunOnDiscreteGpu appInfo property

note.body: I didn't intend to make this as something upstream, it was mainly for us to let users to modify their desktop files so they can let apps to run on their discrete GPU by default. It doesn't use switcheroo-control, it only exports DRI_PRIME=1. I think GNOME was using a similar approach back then and I just followed what they do.

events.target_title: appDisplay: Respect X-KDE-RunOnDiscreteGpu appInfo property

note.body:
>  Do you think we could have an agreed upon property for this instead?

What do you mean exactly?

>  GNOME has always used switcheroo-control to detect whether there are multiple GPUs, given that I wrote both the dual-GPU support and switcheroo-control at the same time ;) switcheroo-control would be used in Solid

I found where is the code for this, we have a DBus interface in powerdevil, which tells to KIO whether a dual GPU is present and I was correct that we don't use switcheroo-control, at least not directly, what we do instead is that we check for existence of **/sys/kernel/debug/vgaswitcheroo/switch**, which is what switcheroo-control is doing if I'm not mistaken. Support for this was added in this review request: https://phabricator.kde.org/D3451.

Meld/Windows: Auto scrolling to changes broken when "Use the system fixed width font" is deactivated

note.body:
Hm. I'm not sure whether the scrolling-synchronization problem is related.

I have all Display settings in Windows at defaults: Sergoe UI 9pt at 96dpi which is 100% scaling.

But now I can't reproduce the problem no more reliably. But what I now do observe is the following: scrolling between changes with "previous/next change" buttons works unreliable. On some files, it works well, on other files it doesn't work at all. But in the latter case, I can make it work by jumping forward and backward through the changes multiple times (which won't be scrolled correctly) until at some point of time, it suddently works perfectly.

This is really a pretty strange bug.

Unfortunately I can't see a pattern in this problem. :(

events.target_title: Meld/Windows: Auto scrolling to changes broken when "Use the system fixed width font" is deactivated

note.body:
Ah, okay. 
You're right. The cursor correctly jumps to the next / previous change, but the scrolling seems to stop right in the middle somewhere, so the search result is not correctly centered.

The choice of font still seems to influence the scrolling problems in some way. It is also interesting that repeating the "goto previous/next change" process seems to "fix" the problem, too.

events.target_title: Meld/Windows: Auto scrolling to changes broken when "Use the system fixed width font" is deactivated

I haven't looked through the code yet, but this shouldn't be too hard.

Scanner buttons support
Add support to save as .tiff format

note.body:
There is hidden TIFF support in the current Debian version, 3.23.2. If I scan a document and then double click on the scanned image (the preview), then the image viewer opens a TIFF version stored in the temporary directory as `scanned-pageXXXXXX.tiff`.

`exiftool` on such file gives the following information:

```
ExifTool Version Number         : 10.40
File Name                       : scanned-page7AFTPZ.tiff
Directory                       : .
File Size                       : 18 MB
File Modification Date/Time     : 2018:09:21 18:30:10+02:00
File Access Date/Time           : 2018:09:21 18:33:27+02:00
File Inode Change Date/Time     : 2018:09:21 18:33:27+02:00
File Permissions                : rw-------
File Type                       : TIFF
File Type Extension             : tif
MIME Type                       : image/tiff
Exif Byte Order                 : Little-endian (Intel, II)
Image Width                     : 2552
Image Height                    : 3531
Bits Per Sample                 : 8 8 8
Compression                     : Adobe Deflate
Photometric Interpretation      : RGB
Fill Order                      : Normal
Strip Offsets                   : 8
Samples Per Pixel               : 3
Rows Per Strip                  : 3531
Strip Byte Counts               : 18651429
X Resolution                    : 300
Y Resolution                    : 300
Planar Configuration            : Chunky
Resolution Unit                 : inches
Image Size                      : 2552x3531
Megapixels                      : 9.0
```

Some beginner users may be requested to output TIFF:s, like for photo printing services, even though other formats like PNG may be usable too.

note.body: Thanks for the help. Your suggestions got rid of this error. Apparently `brew install pygobject3 --with-python@2 gtk+3` installed GdkPixbuf but did not link it. After running `brew install gdk-pixbuf` I got the warning `Warning: gdk-pixbuf 2.38.0 is already installed, it's just not linked`. Using the suggested `brew link gdk-pixbuf` solved that. I also had to manually link `atk`. I guess there is just something wrong with my homebrew installation, which leads to packages not being linked automatically.

events.target_title: Pointer Location issue under Ubuntu 18.04
Pointer Location issue under Ubuntu 18.04

note.body:
The issue was that everytime I pressed the Ctrl key (either left or right) I lost focus on the field I was focused (be it the browser's Developer console while editing HTML/CSS or the terminal's prompt) as if I had pressed the escape key (although not exactly).

**Expected outcome:** Turning Pointer Location ON should show where the pointer is on the screen

**Actual outcome:** Pointer location was ON but not the pointer location was not highlight on pressing Control. Instead of that, the focused field lost focus, making it impossible to copy/paste while editing HTML/CSS on the browser's Developer Console.

**Steps to reproduce:** Under Ubuntu 18.04, I had only to:
1. turn Pointer Location ON
2. Log off user
3. Log in as same user

**Versions**:
· gdm3 --version returns GDM 3.28.2
· gnome-tweaks --version returns 3.28.1
· X server version 11906000

It only happened on X, never on wayland (where I the Pointer Location was correctly highlighted), and I had tested different things:
- on the keyboard mapping layout under settings the control keys never lighted up, though Fn+rightControl did light up the "Menu" key on the layout.
- evtest returned what seemed correct values:
```
Event: time 1536961386.805167, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value 1d
Event: time 1536961386.805167, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 29 (KEY_LEFTCTRL), value 1
Event: time 1536961386.805167, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1536961386.901359, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value 1d
Event: time 1536961386.901359, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 29 (KEY_LEFTCTRL), value 0
Event: time 1536961386.901359, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1536961217.724127, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value 9d
Event: time 1536961217.724127, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 97 (KEY_RIGHTCTRL), value 1
Event: time 1536961217.724127, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1536961217.820477, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value 9d
Event: time 1536961217.820477, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 97 (KEY_RIGHTCTRL), value 0
```

- here's a small video of what happened everytime I pressed any control key: https://www.dropbox.com/s/kpvyri5iuujx0bb/control-pressing.ogv?dl=0
- I tried remapping the Super_L to work as Control_L and viceversa, and the issue still persisted.

Finally, today I created another user to troubleshoot, and everything was working well, so I renamed the .config folder and found the keyboard under my user worked perfectly. From there, renaming folders I found out it was the file inside the dconf folder and since I couldn't troubleshoot it quickly enough decided to reconfigure that part from scratch, only to find that after activating the **Pointer Location** option the Control keys began to show the same issue. Turning it off returned made the issue dissapear.

I hope this helps more to reproduce it, if you would like any other information just ask.

Thanks for your hard work!

events.target_title: Can't change time format with language set to german
gThumb hangs when some mount point is unavailable

note.body:
Gthumb should not scan all drives; what is the point of this?  It should just focus on the targeted directory.  And if there is a hang against a drive, there should be a dialog box showing up after a 1s delay stating which drive it is waiting for and allow the user to cancel, reverting then to the home directory.

BTW, in my case, the hang is not infinite.  It is just a long timeout.  The image eventually shows up.

events.target_title: Thumbnailing images (and others) in Nautilus is dog slow

note.body:
>  gdk-pixbuf-thumbnailer is probably the main reason for the slow thumbnailing.

I don't think so. gdk-pixbuf-thumbnailer isn't that slow, actually. In my test with 150 jpeg images (908MB in total), Thunar took  about 11 second, and a standalone gdk-pixbuf-thumbnailer exactly 14 seconds, to generate x128px thumbnails.

events.target_title: GtkFileChooser search very often incorrectly returns no results
Visual glitches when creating modal windows
Visual glitches when creating modal windows

note.body: Yes, reverting latest commits in js/ui/lightbox.js , 451f4e36, c101196f and fffe7bdf fixes the issue. Thanks!

events.target_title: 3.34 Visual artifact when pop up of delete or create new folder emerge

note.body: Looks like https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/issues/810

events.target_title: 3.34 Visual artifact when pop up of delete or create new folder emerge

note.body: Yes, it's hard to tell from the screencast (it's super glitchy as well) but judging from the description, I'm pretty sure, it's the same issue. You can confirm that by reverting https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/commit/fffe7bdf9cde5817736cb5f7fbe777b5c08d122a mentioned by Sebastian.

events.target_title: Max path bar container width is unnecessary limited
When searching, pressing 'spacebar' selects the file

note.body: Tokenization or Tracker isn't the issue here. `tracker search foo bar` works as expected, so is Nautilus' search with or without Tracker. An unexpected and illogical behavior when user presses space is the issue here, nothing else.

events.target_title: GNOME Flashback steals Super-[a-z] key combinations

note.body:
Sure.
1) Install "gnome-session-flashback", "xmonad", and "dmenu" packages.
2) Create `~/.xmonad/xmonad.hs` with the following content:
```haskell
import XMonad
import XMonad.Config.Gnome

main = xmonad gnomeConfig { modMask = mod4Mask }
```
3) Run "GNOME Flashback (XMonad)" session.
4) Press "Super-p", which should launch dmenu (it should, but it does not).

Thanks for working on Flashback. It's an awesome project! :)

events.target_title: Replace totally unnecessary UTF-8 colons by real ones.
Use of "msgfmt --xml --desktop" not supported by older msgfmt versions
Crash on startup (due to broken locale)

note.body: @piotrdrag at least apply the suggested patch above (or as merge request !1) then...

events.target_title: Replace totally unnecessary UTF-8 colons by real ones.
Replace totally unnecessary UTF-8 colons by real ones.

note.body:
I don't know why there is a thumbs down for this, but let me explain again why it is necessary.
It may well be that gtk/gnome internally totally works in utf-8. That is fine. Its GUI functions work perfectly fine with that. That is even independent of the user's locale. 

But here there are functions called that explicitly convert a string to the user's locale. So that is fundamentally different. The functions return NULL if the string can't be converted. If the user has a locale which doesn't have these special colon characters, Pan will crash. Demanding that the user change their locale is not a solution. Not respecting the user's choice of locale is rude.

Additionally, these special colons have no additional value over normal ASCII colons. So nothing is lost by simply using ASCII colons.

events.target_title: Replace totally unnecessary UTF-8 colons by real ones.
Huge CPU Usage

note.body:
Hello everybody. I also saw similar behaviour. When Gnome Usage is active then `gnome-shell` process is using between 60% and 90% CPU. When I minimize the Gnome Usage window then `gnome-shell` usage is back to normal (under 5%). If I restore the window then the CPU usage of `gnome-shell` is high again.

This is on Ubuntu 18.04.

I have made some screenshots.

1. High CPU usage:
   ![1. High CPU usage](/uploads/f95fc5b7afdba8eb10d00f16585bb342/1._High_CPU_usage.png)

2. Low CPU usage when minimized
   ![2. Low CPU usage when minimized](/uploads/c537c9cfab94b0e7f764062d8bd7d555/2._Low_CPU_usage_when_minimized.png)

3. High CPU usage after restore:

events.target_title: Huge CPU Usage

note.body: When I'm looking at the issues probably this is related/duplicate of #9

events.target_title: Huge CPU Usage

note.body:
I also think that it's probably a problem with gnome-shell because it is the process with high CPU usage, but still other process managers (htop, gnome-system-monitor) does not cause so high CPU usage of gnome-shell. Probably Gnome Usage is updating the graph too frequent compared to the others and that's the reason of high CPU usage of the gnome-shell process.

If there is an option to change the interval in which Gnome Usage is updating the graph probably we can tune it until gnome-shell becomes more efficient and so frequent draws does not cause so high CPU usage.

events.target_title: password not hidden during login

note.body:
I ran into this behavior not long ago, on gnome-shell 3.28.3 (on Debian buster).  I typed my password quickly and automatically into the lock/login screen... and was disturbed to see the whole thing right there in plaintext as I was hitting enter.

When I saw this behavior, it was disturbing enough that I spent some time searching for other reports of it, and experimenting locally, to try to work out how it was triggered.  (I'd mashed the keyboard a bit to get the screen to wake up, so surely it was some sequence of keystrokes.)  But I was unable to come up with a hypothesis that seemed likely.

After reading https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=740043 , I see a sequence that triggers this that may well be what I did:
1. Get to the login prompt, e.g. by hitting some key at the lock screen.
2. Hit the Menu key.
   * My keyboard has one of these between Super_R and Control_R, below Shift_R.
   * Shift-F10 does the same thing; helpful for reproducing on a keyboard without a Menu key.
   * This opens a menu with grayed-out options "Copy" and "Paste", and an option "Show Text".
3. Hit Return.
   * This selects "Show Text".

So the main condition for this to happen, or at least to happen in this way, is to have a Menu key in a place that's easily mashed.  Glancing around, the two colleagues' keyboards I can see are quite different styles from mine and each other but both appear to have Menu keys in the same place as mine, so I think this may be pretty common on non-laptop US keyboards.

Personally I'm tempted to go fiddle my keyboard config to knock out Menu entirely, or make it another Super_R, as I never intentionally use it.

Not sure what a good fix in gnome-shell would be.  One possible hack: ignore Menu on this field, and leave Shift-F10 and right-click as the ways to reach this "Show Text" feature.

Alternatively, if this feature is to exist at all, perhaps it should be somewhere else in the UI anyway -- its current location seems nearly impossible to discover.  If e.g. it were another option parallel to "Log in as another user", it'd be much easier to spot and I think also much harder to trigger by accident.

events.target_title: PNG compression on exported files does not work

note.body:
OK, I am off a little

Original png came from Rawtherapee
6008 x 4008 px
48 bit color depth

Opened in GIMP 2.8 (deleted 2.10.6 as it would not compress png files)
 6008 x 4008 px
83.44 x 55.667 inches
72 x 72 ppi
Color RBG
Size in memory: 228 MB
single layer

Saved file as png with compression (9)
6008 x 4008 px
now 24 bit color depth
reduced size: 20.9 MB

So what I am seeing is not a completely true compression but a reduction of data bits (48 to 24) with compression hense the large reduction in size.

Other programs are doing the same little trick.  However, that does not solve the issue with Gimp 2.10.6 of not performing your compression process

automatic creation of additional images files -- embedded JPEG extracted from DNG

note.body:
I actually don't understand why Shotwell is extracting the JPG contained in RAW/DNG files next to the original one. I saw that several people that uses Shotwell, including me, are also syncing their Photos folder to do backups, this behavior creates a lot more (useless) data to sync and handle, also other Photo viewers will not understand that link between RAW and `_embedded/_shotwell` files.

I would be really happy to be able to put those files into the `~/.thumbs` or `~/.cache` folder for example.

Furthermore, even Shotwell is loosing track of it's own files, here a picture of a RAW file that is displayed twice (I got a few thousands like that, but it's not systematic so there is clearly a bug somewhere): 
- On the right the original RAW file
- On the left the extracted `_embedded` file

![Screenshot_20190813_231116](/uploads/aa425f8a2e13271bd99f3a2d62a1f4cf/Screenshot_20190813_231116.png)

This could be fixed in several ways, I'm ok with all of them:
- Put the `_embedded/_shotwell` files in a separate folder from the Photos directory (strongly prefered and way cleaner)
- Fix this "disconnection" issue between the RAW and developed files
- Do some defensive code and don't index files that ends with `_embedded/_shotwell`

note.body:
I am talking specifically about linking/copying .desktop files from `/usr/share/applications` to the Desktop folder.

To be more precise:

Test 1 - .desktop files:

-   `ln -s /usr/share/applications/org.gnome.Nautilus.desktop`
-   clicking the icon will open the .desktop file in the text-editor.

Test 2 - executable files:

-   `ln -s /usr/bin/nautilus`
-   clicking the (empty) icon will open Nautilus.

So it's the opposite of what you claim.

PS.
I also don't get why starting a .desktop file is more secure than an executable, since those can call any insecure executable as well-

events.target_title: libtesseract segfaults with tesseract 4.0.0

note.body:
This is not a but at all (it's a feature!)

If you check [the tesseract commit](https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/commit/3292484f67af8bdda23aa5e510918d0115785291) they explicitly say they want the `C` locale:
>  Normal C++ programs like those which are built for tesseract automatically
> set the locale "C".
>
> There can be different locale settings if the tesseract library is used
> in other software.
> 
> A wrong locale can cause wrong results from sscanf which is used at
> different places in the tesseract code, so make sure that we have the
> right locale settings and fail if that is not the case.

events.target_title: libtesseract segfaults with tesseract 4.0.0

note.body:
In fact, unsetting locale with `locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, "")` doesn't unset other locales `LC_*`. So when you unset, all other locale get their previous value back. I'm not sure if I'm clear here, check the following (more self-explaining) code:
```python
import locale
print(locale.getlocale(locale.LC_CTYPE))
# ('fr-FR-, 'UTF-8')
locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, "C")
# 'C'
print(locale.getlocale(locale.LC_CTYPE))
# (None, None)
locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, "")
# 'LC_CTYPE=fr_FR.UTF-8;LC_NUMERIC=fr_FR.utf8;LC_TIME=fr_FR.utf8;LC_COLLATE=fr_FR.UTF-8;LC_MONETARY=fr_FR.utf8;LC_MESSAGES=fr_FR.UTF-8;LC_PAPER=fr_FR.utf8;LC_NAME=fr_FR.UTF-8;LC_ADDRESS=fr_FR.UTF-8;LC_TELEPHONE=fr_FR.UTF-8;LC_MEASUREMENT=fr_FR.utf8;LC_IDENTIFICATION=fr_FR.UTF-8'
print(locale.getlocale(locale.LC_CTYPE))
# ('fr_FR', 'UTF-8')
```

events.target_title: libtesseract segfaults with tesseract 4.0.0

note.body:
It would seems like `locale.getdefaultlocale` is not modified by `LC_ALL` (because `getdefaultlocale` used the `$LANG` variable):

```python
import locale
print(locale.getdefaultlocale())
# ('fr_FR', 'UTF-8')
locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, "C")
print(locale.getdefaultlocale())
# ('fr_FR', 'UTF-8')
```

So the proposed workaround could maybe be implemented at submodule `src/pyocr/libtesseract/__init__.py`

But surely, this is something which must be widely tested…

events.target_title: Deselects task/memo list when started in Calendar view

note.body:
Here is a description of the problem and how to duplicate it.

Have just now discovered this issue also exists in Ubuntu 18.10

Create USB live boot from ISO.

Install Evolution 3.30.0.
Open Evolution and Restore from a backup file.  Enter e-mail password.
Should be in Calendar View.  Task list is present.

Switch to Tasks View.  Personal list is NOT checked.  Personal for Calendar and Memos are.

Switch to Calendar View and Quit Evolution.

Start Evolution.  Should be in Calendar View - where it was quit.
Task List is NOW EMPTY.

Switch to Tasks and Check Personal
Leave in Task View and Quit.

Start Evolution.  Should be in Task View - where it was quit.
Personal Tasks are still checked.

Switch to Calendar View and Quit Evolution.
Start Evolution.  Should be in Calendar View - where it was quit.
Switch to Tasks View.  Personal list is NOT checked.

Quitting Evolution in Calendar view keeps unchecking the Personal Tasks.  This also happens in 3.28-5.  Everything stays checked (the expected behavior) in 3.28-1-2.

This is a regression.  You have everything you need from me now to repeat the failure and to address it.  The fix for me now, is to blacklist Evolution updates.

![initial](/uploads/0c5cb336fcb00c12723822ee402abf72/initial.jpg)![should-be](/uploads/778e485a27720d8efd97a4676fc31c94/should-be.jpg)![is](/uploads/8a8bff82f73610be753f855c30041772/is.jpg)![result](/uploads/754e3e4ecbecebcc8eb4d3b08911c1ba/result.jpg)

note.body:
For Visual C++ on 64-bit systems, int is 32bits, long is 32bits, llong is 64bits.  So %llu is probably right for 64-bit MinGW. Microsoft prefers the unportable %I64u in their compiler's headers, though.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/cpp/integer-limits?view=vs-2019

note.body:
Hello guys,

added a few debugging to [js/ui/background.js](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/js/ui/background.js#L715), like this:

```js
        Tweener.addTween(oldBackgroundActor,
                         { opacity: 0,
                           time: FADE_ANIMATION_TIME,
                           transition: 'easeOutQuad',
                           onComplete() {
 /* debugging aids -------> */ dmp(oldBackgroundActor.background, 0, oldBackgroundActor.background);
                               oldBackgroundActor.background.run_dispose();
                               oldBackgroundActor.destroy();
                           }
                         });

```
and noticed that after issuing
```bash
gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.background picture-uri \
'file:///usr/share/backgrounds/gnome/adwaita-night.jpg'
```
```onComplete``` handler is called twice, thus second call causes the error

```log
gnome-shell[10410]: ==[object instance proxy GIName:Meta.Background jsobj@0x7fd59a38b400 native@0x5612b43fbdf0]==
gnome-shell[10410]: [properties]
gnome-shell[10410]: [functions]
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- __metaclass__( args:0 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- _construct( args:0 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- bind_property( args:4 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- disconnect( args:1 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- notify( args:1 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- set( args:1 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- set_color( args:1 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- set_file( args:2 )
gnome-shell[10410]: [objects]
gnome-shell[10410]: -obj- _delegate: [object Object] [recursion]
gnome-shell[10410]: ==[object (FINALIZED) instance proxy GIName:Meta.Background jsobj@0x7fd59a38b400 native@0x5612b43fbdf0]==
gnome-shell[10410]: [properties]
gnome-shell[10410]: [functions]
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- __metaclass__( args:0 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- _construct( args:0 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- bind_property( args:4 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- disconnect( args:1 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- notify( args:1 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- run_dispose( args:0 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- set( args:1 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- set_color( args:1 )
gnome-shell[10410]: -fun- set_file( args:2 )
gnome-shell[10410]: [objects]
gnome-shell[10410]: -obj- _delegate: [object Object] [recursion]
gnome-shell[10410]: Object Meta.Background (0x5612b43fbdf0), has been already deallocated — impossible to access it. This might be caused by the object having been destroyed from C code using something such as destroy(), dispose(), or remove() vfuncs.
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: == Stack trace for context 0x5612b43c7290 ==
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #0   5612b4f553e0 i   resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/background.js:759 (7fd59a40d790 @ 53)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #1   5612b4f55358 i   resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/tweener.js:91 (7fd59a8ccf70 @ 37)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #2   5612b4f552b8 i   resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/tweener/tweener.js:208 (7fd59a8dd790 @ 54)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #3   5612b4f55198 i   resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/tweener/tweener.js:342 (7fd59a8dd820 @ 1742)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #4   5612b4f55108 i   resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/tweener/tweener.js:355 (7fd59a8dd8b0 @ 100)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #5   5612b4f55090 i   resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/tweener/tweener.js:370 (7fd59a8dd940 @ 10)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #6   7ffeaa0d9320 b   resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/signals.js:128 (7fd59a8c18b0 @ 386)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #7   5612b4f55000 i   resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/tweener.js:207 (7fd59a8d9790 @ 159)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #8   7ffeaa0da290 b   resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/_legacy.js:82 (7fd59a8b0b80 @ 71)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10410]: #9   5612b4f54f80 i   resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/tweener.js:182 (7fd59a8d9700 @ 15)

```

Temporarily fixed it for myself like this:
```patch
--- a/gnome-shell/js/ui/background.js	2018-10-05 12:49:18.004850155 +1000
+++ a/gnome-shell/js/ui/background.js	2018-10-05 12:52:18.359101093 +1000
@@ -717,8 +717,10 @@
                            time: FADE_ANIMATION_TIME,
                            transition: 'easeOutQuad',
                            onComplete() {
-                               oldBackgroundActor.background.run_dispose();
-                               oldBackgroundActor.destroy();
+                             oldBackgroundActor.background.toString().match(/^.object .FINALIZED/) || (
+                               oldBackgroundActor.background.run_dispose(),
+                               oldBackgroundActor.destroy()
+                             );
                            }
                          });
     },

```

which is inelegant and wrong (e.g. one day underlying ```toString()``` will change), but still working...

It would be fine to discover a reason why it is called twice, and fix it there, instead. Authors? Anyone?


Hoping this will help.
Thanks

**NB**. Unsure if my patch affects bg changing animation, but at least I cannot see such an animation in VM. Did not test it on the real hardware yet though

note.body: Note that this issue also applies to the way S/MIME signatures are presented to the user by Evolution.

events.target_title: Improve handling of suspiciously signed/encrypted emails (multiparts)

note.body:
the whole partially-signed / partially-encrypted flexibility of PGP + MIME is a hell :/

while partially-signed may happen in-the-wild (e.g., forwarded messages or mailing lists that add a footer), partially-encrypted should *not* happen unless PGP/Inline is used to encrypted a multipart email (in which case it is imho sane to show only the first encrypted part and either opt-in to show the other ones or directly show them as attachments).

events.target_title: Improve handling of suspiciously signed/encrypted emails (multiparts)

note.body:
Update: Here's a full (public) report on the issue:
https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1904/1904.07550.pdf

For Evolution, CVE-2019-10733 was assigned for reply-based `decryption oracles`.

events.target_title: Image moved to end of list on save
Go to previous/next image using arrow keys

note.body: This may be because the arrow keys are used to tweak the slider values when editing an image. For example, when changing the brightness of an image, you can use the arrow keys to move the slider back and forth.

note.body:
```
grayson@kaveri:~$ G_DEBUG=fatal-criticals epiphany

(epiphany:22746): GLib-CRITICAL **: 11:30:45.792: Source ID 1299 was not found when attempting to remove it
Trace/breakpoint trap (core dumped)
grayson@kaveri:~$ G_DEBUG=fatal-criticals epiphany
**
ERROR:../lib/ephy-time-helpers.c:79:eel_strdup_strftime: assertion failed: (converted != NULL)
Aborted (core dumped)
grayson@kaveri:~$ G_DEBUG=fatal-criticals epiphany

(epiphany:22871): GLib-CRITICAL **: 11:32:07.787: Source ID 875 was not found when attempting to remove it
Trace/breakpoint trap (core dumped)
grayson@kaveri:~$ G_DEBUG=fatal-criticals epiphany

(epiphany:22921): GLib-CRITICAL **: 11:32:34.849: Source ID 877 was not found when attempting to remove it
Trace/breakpoint trap (core dumped)
grayson@kaveri:~$
``

The first time I open Epiphany with varialble set, Epiphany crashed immediately. Second time is when the browser opened and I visited preference and that lead to assertion failed message. Third time I open Epiphany it crashed and the fourth time when I open Epiphany, the browser opened and I tried visiting google.com and that lead me to a crash.

However, it seems opening Preference did not cause a GLib-CRITICAL crash.

`LANG=en_US.UTF-8`

$ unset LANG
$ source /etc/profile.d/locale.sh

events.target_title: Hardcoded default port breaks "bookmarks" from `ssh_config`

note.body:
The relevant change is https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gvfs/merge_requests/33 / 1a38caf8bcb4e02b68f8062319ef7736796a7e64. It also broke my workflow.

As far as I understand, it is not an appropriate fix for the original bug. https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gvfs/+bug/343000 can be rephrased as:

“When I specify an URL with an explicit port number that happens to be 22, gvfs not normalize the URL to one without a port number. (And therefore still pass `-p 22` to the `ssh` command rather than not specify a port number.)”

Instead, the change is:

“When an URL does not specify a port number, pass `-p 22` to the `ssh` command rather than let use its own default (which might be set in some configuration file).”

The net effect in the specific situation of the original bug report is the same, but this has undesirable side effects in other situations. Now there is apparently no way to use the port number from OpenSSH configuration files such as `~/.ssh/config` without duplicating it in the URL given to Nautilus/gvfs.

events.target_title: Implement header bar

note.body:
As it is right now, a large number of people automatically jump to Tilix if they're interested in using a terminal under GNOME, due to its following of the GNOME HIG and the headerbar. And while I respect and am enthused by gnunn's work, this isn't the behavior that should be typical for the GNOME ecosystem. The default apps should be the ones that best integrate into the system and follow the overall philosophy, not a third party app that is not part of the GNOME project in any way. 

As @bertob said, this isn't about personal preference. The GNOME HIG is the way that the GNOME platform has been designed to work and feel and run. It is the lifeblood of GNOME's design. It shouldn't be an optional hidden thing; this, by the standards set for the project, is what a modern GNOME app should be. Without a headerbar, GNOME Terminal simply isn't a modern core GNOME application.

events.target_title: cannot be configured to not hibernate if hardware supports it

note.body:
To me, "suspend, then hibernate" is a different choice, just like "suspend" and "hibarnate" are different choices, so it should have its own place in the UI selection as proposed in the opening post above.

Before I had time to look into what was happening, I had two instances where I needed to look  something up quickly on my computer and the two to three minute delay of waiting for it to boot and load its suspended state from disk was very inconvenient. There was no problem like the ones outlined in the OP, but, when I chose to let the system suspend, I was choosing to suspend to RAM, not to disk, and so was surprised by the result. I am sure for newer hardware with a better processor and an SSD instead of a HDD the difference between suspending to RAM and to disk is less pronounced. I don't know if my experience is typical or behind the times for the average user today (ie maybe there will be a time when suspending to disk has negligible difference to suspending to RAM, but I don't know that we are there yet).

events.target_title: Gimp Crash Debug
Add percentage
Add percentage

note.body:
Well, first of all I said "in addition to", not "instead of". 
Second, it has real user cases. When you format in ext4/3/2, you still leave 5% of the fs to system. Not 10GB. Not 47.32GB. 5%, which is the default.
If your fs is filled at more than 95%, you're almost done.
It is even more urgent on a fs with snapshots, like btrfs. 
Third:

note.body: Thanks for the advice, it’s done!

events.target_title: Rename the baobab binary to gnome-disk-usage-analyzer

note.body:
Yes it is what I want, sorry for the lack of clarity.

It is the name I know because I discovered baobab through Gnome Shell graphical interface, in which it not identified as baobab *at all*.
In fact, Gnome Shell only shows it as “Disk usage analyzer”, not Baobab.

Though, I recently needed to access it through terminal because I wanted root access to it, as the normal way (i.e. non-terminal non-root access) did not let me list a freshly mounted volume (it appeared root or non-root access was not the cause of my problem after all, which I did solve and is not the subject of this issue).

Anyway, most graphical & non-graphical tools of the gnome microcosm (at least most I am used to) do have some decent predictability & consistency in their according binary name: for the disks utility tool it is *gnome-disks*, for Gnome Calendar you have the quite obvious *gnome-calendar*, etc.
I am certain there are other counter-examples than baobab, but baobab is, on this matter, quite an example: if you discover the software graphically, you discover an application named “Disk Usage Analyzer” (modulo your language).
However, if you want to launch the app from a terminal instead of using its .desktop file, whatever the reason (accessing the app through an SSH X session, or with root access, etc.), and given you never saw the about page beforehand, once in the terminal, you’ll feel totally helpless while crawling for gnome-\*disk\* or \*disk\* binaries, and not finding baobab, obviously.

I have no preference between baobab & “Disk Usage Analyzer” (and according (gnome-)disk-usage-analyzer from terminal) as for the actual name of the app, but I do expect some consistency between DM access & terminal access to it: for instance the widely known gparted graphical app is not titled “Volumes Partitions Editor” or whatever, but GParted. 

I hope I made myself clearer.

events.target_title: g_thread_pool_free not cleaning up thread local stroage

note.body:
And here is the minimal example, compiled on Fedora 28:

```
#include <glib.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

static void worker_thread(gpointer data, gpointer user_data)
{
}

int main(void) {
    /* thread pool with one single TPM thread */
    GThreadPool *pool;

    pool = g_thread_pool_new(worker_thread,
                             NULL,
                             1,
                             TRUE,
                             NULL);

    g_thread_pool_free(pool, TRUE, TRUE);
    return 0;
}
```

events.target_title: New search behavior using type-ahead search by default

note.body:
Sorry for the non-technical comment, but what I'm observing is the following: nautilus team has their minds set on doing away with the type-ahead feature, without realizing they can simply disable it as the default behavior and do their current search. A lot of people are upset about this, I don't mean the whole world, but a lot of people, but nautilus team thinks they're right somehow and won't consider compromise which doesn't at all go against their vision for the search. 

Now, more practically: the maintenance cost for keeping the type-ahead as a non-default option should be negligible (unless the code is awful, I don't know). The benefit for the nautilus team is more support and much less heat from the community (as now the community would not have to go through the pain of building with a custom patch and all to get their wanted functionality back).

Just my two cents, sorry if I'm off topic for this thread.

events.target_title: RSVG assumes PPI different from other common SVG compatible software
RSVG assumes PPI different from other common SVG compatible software

note.body: Or put differently, rsvg assumes that 1pt = 1.25px while others assume 1pt = 1.33333px.

events.target_title: RSVG assumes PPI different from other common SVG compatible software

note.body: Great, thanks. This works. I was sure to have tried it but apparently not correctly. I guess what's left then is the question why this is not the default as it is in other applications.

events.target_title: RSVG assumes PPI different from other common SVG compatible software

note.body:
I don't know what an ABI is. 

Anyway, I think it it should be highlighted more that RSVG might by default result in different rendering from today's standard. At least I have not easily found out about this problem. For example, in the command-help, mention that RSVG has a default value of 90 for historic reasons while 96 is the standard. Maybe even give out a warning when using the non-standard default value?

Here is why I think this matters: I recently ran into a problem with a typesetting application which used RSVG for conversion leading to the wrong results. But since the application has been using RSVG in this way for a while it cannot so easily change to their standards either...

Hi Didier, 

Thanks for your comment,

Have a Happy day

events.target_title: rsvg-convert text-anchor middle end causes strange position issue with certain fonts / outputs

note.body:
Hi, I also ran into this issue.
One thing I noticed is that when you render multiple pages using librsvg + Cairo from exactly the same SVG, only the first page exhibits the problem and subsequent pages are fine.

In fact, when there's multiple `<text>` elements on the first page, only the first one is botched.
Therefore, I am using the following workaround:

```
    <text x="40%" y="20mm" text-anchor="middle"> </text>
    <text x="40%" y="20mm" text-anchor="middle">Actual text goes here</text>
```

If the first `<text>` is omitted, the second one is misplaced (on the first page only).

The above would suggest the problem is indeed in Cairo, but it's hard to tell without knowledge of internals...

**EDIT:**
Actually, scratch the above workaround. It works _sometimes_ but not reliably.
What I'm doing now instead is to first render the first page into a zero-sized clip region,
then I reset the clip region and render all the pages as normal. That means the first render of the first page
is invisible, but apparently resets some internal states such that after that, the `<text>`s are positioned correctly.

events.target_title: WIP: clutter: Deliver events sooner when possible

note.body:
Don't think it should land yet. I've tried using this patch with !189 (and also !117 and !171 but it probably shouldn't be relevant) and my 1000hz mouse in a Xorg session and dragging a window around when there are other opened in the back results in 100% CPU usage on one thread (i7 2600K) and very (very) stuttery movement. Can't reproduce with the same patches but this one.
Also, if I plug in my cheap 125hz mouse and use that to drag windows, it seems tolerable, though there are still huge spikes in the process monitor.

events.target_title: WIP: clutter: Deliver events sooner when possible

note.body:
I can confirm these results (fyi, I have a 60hz monitor).

With just !168 and !189 + gjs!236 + gnome-shell!265, the stuttering when dragging windows in a Xorg session is very bad compared to a similar setup but without !168 or with regular packages.

With !270 it seems to improve the situation slightly, but the difference is small and could very well be a placebo effect, and it's still way much worse than without !168. 

But in both cases, !168 causes very heavy load on 1 core.

~~I will report on performance with other shells and Wayland (with egl-wayland maybe?) later.~~

events.target_title: WIP: clutter: Deliver events sooner when possible

note.body:
When I drag just gnome-terminal, it's lag free and smooth, same when it's just Nautilus.
But if I open both and start dragging one of the windows, it's still fairly smooth, but I start to notice some very slight but noticeable stutter.
And I did not observe any significant changes with !277 or when launching chromium with `__GL_SYNC_TO_VBLANK=0`.

WebKitWebProcess crashes when displaying email
WebKitWebProcess crashes when displaying email

note.body:
> What makes you think that WebKitWebProcess crashes?

Evolution says it did, or at least it displays a banner with the message "WebKitWebProcess crashed when displaying the message. [...]" above the display area.

events.target_title: WebKitWebProcess crashes when displaying email

note.body:
> By any chance, is it possible to provide a backtrace of that crash, please? I do not know what tool Debian uses to catch the crashes, being it Fedora it's ABRT.

I would love to, but I'm not currently aware of any Debian tools that would allow me to do that.

> Could you try with Epiphany, please? Or even simpler would be with /usr/libexec/webkit2gtk-4.0/MiniBrowser https://www.gnome.org (the actual path to the MiniBrowser can differ in your distribution).

Hmm. When I executed `/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/webkit2gtk-4.0/MiniBrowser`, which appears to be the path of MiniBrowser for Debian, it tried to load www.gnome.org but couldn't display it. The error message seems to be the same as Evolution's:

> WebKitWebProcess: ../../src/hb-object.hh:253: Type* hb_object_reference(Type*) [with Type = hb_unicode_funcs_t]: Assertion `hb_object_is_valid (obj)' failed.

So it seems like it's a general issue with the WebKit library. Do you, perchance, know where I should report this?

events.target_title: WebKitWebProcess crashes when displaying email
WebKitWebProcess crashes when displaying email

note.body:
> I would love to, but I'm not currently aware of any Debian tools that would allow me to do that.

Actually, let me correct that. I just found [this useful Debian Wiki article](https://wiki.debian.org/HowToGetABacktrace) and should be able to provide you with a backtrace in a bit; The necessary packages are still downloading/installing.

events.target_title: WebKitWebProcess crashes when displaying email

note.body:
> WebKitGTK+ has their own bugzilla:
https://bugs.webkit.org/enter_bug.cgi?product=WebKit

> You can report it on https://bugs.webkit.org, starting the title of the bug with [GTK] and selecting the "Webkit Gtk" component.

Thanks, that's good to know!

> Right, using gdb. Unfortunately the WebKitWebProcess is a process run by an application, thus it's harder to debug it. I'd probably replace it with a script which will run the original binary under gdb and when gdb stops you'll be able to execute `t a a bt` in the gdb prompt, which will show the backtrace of the crash, but it's a little challenge to make it right, also due to extra arguments being passed to that process.

Yeah, I noticed that when running gdb, too. gdb just goes past the WebKit error and continues on normally. I also wasn't able to find a way to inspect a previously run thread yet.

Just so I understood you correctly here, you're thinking of a script like this:

```bash
#!/bin/bash

gdb `which evolution`
```

And then run it in gdb. Is that correct?

> I suggest posting the backtrace here first so we can look it over before reporting the bug there.

That sounds reasonable.

Michael, please find the new backtrace here: https://gitlab.gnome.org/snippets/376

As Milan already pointed out, the crash is not caused by one particular email. It can be reproduced with any email I have access to in Evolution at the moment as well as with `MiniBrowser` from the WebKitGTK+ package.

Also, did I understand you correctly that I should create a new issue on the WebKit issue tracker with the new information?

Milan, the HarfBuzz version that's installed on my system appears to be 1.9.0-1. Maybe that introduced the error to the WebKit library?
